div.p: Your letter of July 7th came a couple of days ago. You are generous and reasonable, and I thank you very much for writing me such a nice letter. Persons of our profession are not always either the one or the other, and I assure you that I appreciate your attitude very much.

Curiously enough, I had not heard of Ezra's scheme, directly, or even indirectly exactly, until I read your letter in the “Literary Review.” I am rather sorry you printed it there, because the “Double Dealer,” in which Kreymborg's letter came out, has almost no circulation. It is a little amateur magazine which I believe does not pay for contributions, and I think very few people would have heard of Ezra's Bel Esprit had you not broadcasted it in your letter to the “Literary Review.” As I wrote you, Ezra wrote to Harriet about Eliot, but Harriet gave me no idea that he had mentioned any such scheme as his Bel Esprit. I had a most extraordinary letter from him in March in which he wrote that I was on the wrong tack, but that there was a chance for me to return to the fold. Did I want to? If I did, he would tell me more, etc., etc., etc. Of course I smelt a desire for money, so I wrote back as nice a letter as I knew how, but took occasion to put in three angles of my point of view. I said; “Personally, I am friendly; aesthetically, I am obstinate; financially, I am broke.” And I supposed I should hear no more, and I have not. I have done considerable wondering as to what he really wanted, and now you have cleared up my doubts. He wanted money for his Bel Esprit scheme which, of course, I entirely disapprove of.

I do think it is too bad about Mr. Eliot. Of course, he is in a horrid position now, and it is equally true that you never meant to put him in
an awkward hole. It is a great pity that he cannot throw up the bank. Richard, is it consumption? That occurred to me after I had written to you. Is it not possible for him to earn enough money to live in Switzerland or Colorado and write for his living? He could if he were writing for American papers, they pay much better than the English ones do. I am sincerely sorry for him, and if I were not so strapped, I should be inclined to do a little something anyway, but please believe that I am not talking through my hat when I tell you that I have only enough for those calls which are nearer home than Mr. Eliot's can possibly be.

I see you everywhere now. The “Times” article came yesterday, but I have not had time to glance at it yet. I shall, however, read it very soon and write you on the subject. Also, in the “North American Review” comes your paper on “Marivaux and Marivaudage”; that last is a splendid subject. Fascinating character, Marivaux. I should very much like to talk over my Keats book with you, for I think we should have just the same point of view. One of the things I want particularly to prove is how un-Greek he was in every particular; in fact, I think my book will mostly consist in going against the attitude of his previous biographers. From the point of view of pure scholarship, I have raked up some extraordinary things on this side of the ocean. In unpublished material, I shall have in my book: five letters of Keats; an account by Taylor, taken from the lips of Mr. Abbey, of Keats's mother; a good many unknown readings of poems; a number of letters by friends of Keats from which I shall draw extracts; some extracts of an unknown correspondence of Fanny Brawne's; and the annotations of five volumes owned by Keats and marked by him. We used to turn our noses at exact scholarship in those early days,
but I have come to the conclusion (along with you and Eliot as a matter of fact, for we seem to agree on this) that exact scholarship is highly essential provided you have imagination and insight over it. I hope the book will be out in the Autumn of 1923. I understand from Houghton Mifflin that Constable is to issue it in England, and then I expect the storm to burst in all the conservative magazines.
Well, no more at this present writing, as our ancestors used to say. I will write you again when I have read your papers.
